Title:
Phylogeography of Haplocarpha rueppellii (Asteraceae)
suggests a geographical barrier between Mt Kenya and Mt Aberdare since
the Pleistocene
Keywords:
East Africa, afro-montane, afro-alpine, gene flow,
phylogeography, geographical barrier, Haplocarpha rueppellii
Abstract:
Haplocarpha rueppellii is mainly distributed in the alpine
grassland and moorland of East Africa. In this study, we sampled 61
individuals of 6 populations from 5 Eastern Africa mountains, Elgon,
Aberdare, Kenya, Kilimanjaro and Bale. We sequenced 1 nuclear and 3
chloroplast fragments, and conducted phylogenetic analysis, divergence
time estimation, principal coordinate analysis and gene flow analyses to
investigate the phylogeographic structure of this species. The
phylogenetic analysis and principal coordinate analysis suggest that the
species consists of two major groups, one is the populations from Elgon,
Aberdare and Bale, the other one is from Kenya and Kilimanjaro. The
results also support that the character of multicellular hairs is
mutable and therefore no change of the taxonomic concept of this species
is needed. Divergence time estimation suggest that H. rueppellii has
established in Kenya and Aberdare one million years ago, however, low
migration rate between the two mountains were suggested by gene flow
analysis. In addition, diversification of this species seems not to be
affected by the East Africa Rift Valley. Different from previous
phylogeographic studies, which show close relationship between Aberdare
and Kenya, this study indicates a barrier for plant migration and gene
flow between the two mountains.
